title: 114_hr1090
content: The "Retail Investor Protection Act" prohibits the Secretary of Labor from defining fiduciaries under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act until the Securities and Exchange Commission issues a final rule on standards of conduct for brokers and dealers. Amendments are also made to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include requirements for the Commission to provide a report to specific committees before promulgating a rule on brokers and dealers operating under different standards of conduct. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to address brokers and dealers operating under different standards of conduct compared to investment advisors. Alternative remedies aim to reduce confusion and harm to retail investors by simplifying titles and enhancing disclosure. The curr_chunk discusses the potential impact of adopting a uniform fiduciary standard of conduct for brokers, dealers, and investment advisors. It highlights concerns about how this could affect commissions, proprietary products, and the ability to engage in principal transactions. The curr_chunk discusses the economic analysis required to support the Commission's conclusions on the impact of adopting a uniform fiduciary standard of conduct for brokers, dealers, and investment advisors. Additionally, it outlines the requirements for promulgating a rule to reduce confusion or harm to retail customers. The Commission must consider differences in registration, supervision, and examination requirements for brokers, dealers, and investment advisors when proposing rules for brokers or dealers. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 27, 2015. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
